Like most situations, this is one that can be resolved through peaceful negotiation.
If you muster your forces at the shoreline, the enemy may back away from such a display.

This is clearly a ruse of the most base and transparent kind. To let him live after attempting such chicanery would be an insult to the tribe and the gods.
The man has played the entire tribe for fools. This trickery cannot stand. Find him and destroy him.
This is, admittedly, a most dubious request, yet the chance of gaining Rome’s favour is surely worth the risk.
There is little that can be done to undo the sullying of your reputation, and no guarantee he can be caught and brought to justice. Let him go, and move on.

Accept the money and return him. Roma must solve its own disputes, lest you be accused of meddling to increase your own power.
Leo has clearly been wronged. Promise to escort him to Roma and earn the title of Holy Roman Emperor!
Try and change the subject as discreetly as possible by giving your assent.
Risk the Shahanshah’s wrath by confronting him directly.

Please the king, but risk deeply wounding the pride of your people when word gets out.
Tell him you see his point of view but would be no king if you failed to defend your subjects.

This character has become a statesman in your faction.
This man is too important to lose, yet Alcuin will doubtless be unhappy if he is forced to stay.
Alcuin remains your most important scholar, the kingdom will be worse off without him.
Letting Alcuin leave is what the scholar wants. Who are we to deny such a request?
Risking the ire of Alcuin could be as bad as losing him. Do not burn bridges, and let him go.

Rebellion
Ybor’s rhetoric needs no divine backing – he chooses the king.
Is a god not greater than a king? Ybor accepts the priest’s offer.
His words laced with authority, Ybor lashes the farmers into action.
Any man may take life, only the great may give it.
Feeling Godan’s presence surrounding him, Ybor plunges into the fire.
By slaying the evil before it does harm, a healer will never be needed.

Become the "Kingdom of the Vikings".
You could earn the respect of Charlemagne by remaining defiant, though you may just as easily miss an opportunity to sway his opinion.
Ceding Ravenna will diminish your strength, but honouring Pepin’s agreement will sow goodwill between you and the Papacy.
The threat Charlemagne poses is great. Relenting and ceding Ravenna may be the wisest option at this stage.
Comply with Charlemagne’s demands and cede Ravenna to the Papal States. This is now the only way to avoid war with him.
Grovel to Charlemagne and he may side with you in this matter, but you may lose the respect of your people by doing so.
Strategically speaking, Ravenna is not a region to be given up easily, but refusing to accept the Pope’s demands will likely draw his anger.
Offering a large sum of money could lead the Pope to relinquish his claims over this territory.
If this region is too important, or if your pride too great, then war with Charlemagne is now the only option left open to you.
Godan will see he is repaid.
Alone, Ybor steps forward with sweet words of reason and persuasion.
Words can turn a man’s head and pierce his heart.
With fiery exhortations, Ybor plunges into the heart of the mob.
Your direct and unwavering refusal to accept peace will surely inspire your men!
A loyalist army now defends Carloman's capital.
Pagans rise up in anger at the ruins of the Irminsul!
Peace with the Kingdom of Mercia.
All pagans will hear of this massacre, you can only hope that they will see the light.
Killing their leaders will send a strong message to the other captives.
Forcing their leaders to accept baptism could sway the others.
Your mercy would surely show the Saxons that peaceful co-existence is mutually beneficial.
